This dude does best in a larger glass to push all of that acidity and alc (18%) around to make a rich and bold drinking experience. This is a nama just like your dad used to drink (or your mom if she was ballsy!) and does far better with foods of all types as it is strong and confident and compliments without getting overwhelmed. This nama will warm your cold winter body! WORD: Big WINE: Huge reds/Boozy whitesBEER: Stouts FOODS: Meats, savory stews, salty oily bar fare.(Winter 2015)

Denshin Haru Junmai Ginjo Nama.description: This is a seasonal released sake. Call True Sake at 415-355-9555 foravailability, size, and pricing.With a nose filled with cherry, peach, and melon aromas. Say hello to a smooth and fun unpasteurized sake in a killer bottle with a special hidden sticker. This clean, bright, and fun brew drinks semi-thick, semi-chewy, and semi-dry with a dry finish. Look for hints of citrus, strawberry, melon, and red apple on a smooth and even flow. This is a very flavorful nama that drinks very Ginjo-like and is bright but not too jagged or brash. If you like silky then this sake is for you. WORD: Smooth WINE: Soft reds/smooth whites BEER: Fruity ales FOODS: Shellfish, oysters, sushi, sashimi. (2019)Judging by the hidden flower sticker under the cap tape you will deduce that this is a seasonally released unpasteurized sake. The nose jumps with cherry, peach, red apple, and mint aromas. My notes read: “A great brew to go check out the cherry blossoms with.” And basically that means that this nama is light, bright, fun, and fresh. It is brisk and frisky, but yet controlled and very refreshing. It drinks lively and vivid, but with a gentle understanding of your palate. Look for subtle fruit tones that are bouncy as they slide through the mouth. A smaller cups makes for a more zesty play, mid-size for a more fleshy feel, and a wine glass for more overall balance. Haru’18 is a real winner! WORD: Fun WINE: Zesty reds/Crisp whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Great with clean sushi and sashimi, but also good with American sushi spice.(2018)

Denshin Natsu Junmai Daiginjo Nama.description: The nose on this seasonally released summer unpasteurized sake is a wonderful collection of cherry, grape, lemon, and other citrus aromas. This is a smooth, fun, and fruity brew. With a choice plumpness and layers of flavors that balance with a tender acidity. Look for honey, apple, sweet pears, and lemon honey tea flavors that drink bright and chewy. Semi-thick, fleshy, and full. This drinks like a Junmai Daiginjo on steroids that makes everything larger and more robust, but still fun and not cloying. And there aren’t many Junmai Daiginjo Nama out there so this is a treat. Another great seasonal sake from a great brewery that knows how to capture sunshine in the bottle. WORD: Sunny WINE: Fat reds/Plump whites BEER: Fat Belgian Ales FOODS: International spicy fare, American sushi, fruit and cheese plates.2018 - The nose on this very fresh unpasteurized sake is an interesting collection of sweet tomato relish, pear, and cantaloupe aromas. Say hello to a Nama Junmai Daiginjo! There are not a lot of those out there so it is important to taste one while you can. Why? Because now you are dealing with elegant nama zake. Typically namas tend to be heavy and zesty and very lively, this summer brew is slippery and soft with very classy silky qualities that speak to those who like very refined sakes. It is a true Daiginjo experience with layers of ripe flavors and gentle feelings. Look for hints of pear, melon, and rice krispie treats in a fluid that does better in a larger wine-like glass. WORD: Elegant WINE: Beaujolais/velvety whites BEER: Creamy Ales FOODS: Sunny summer picnic dishes, shellfish, oysters.

Esshu Sakura Biyori Ginjo.description: The nose on this year’s version of Sakurabiyori is filled with floral, melon, sweet rice, and fruit juice aromas. Wow! Talk about a gentle and clean ginjo with great feeling and flavor. At 14% alc. you’d think this brew would almost drink too light, but forget that! Even, smooth, silky, juicy, fruity, light and simply elegant this Ginjo is a pleasure in the palate. Look for powder sugar, melon, light pear, and a hint of sweet rice flavors that ride the very pristine and clean flow. A mid-size glass captures the best feeling and flavor relation, and the rest is pure silky magic. WORD: Gentle WINE: Soft reds / floral whites BEER: Light Ales FOODS: Sashimi, clean flavors, shellfish, oysters, grilled fish and chicken. (2018)First and foremost, Esshu is drinking great this season! The nose is splendid collection of cherry, plum, white raisin, and sweet rice aromas, which translates into the flavor nicely. Bright and clean with a dash of fruit tones but overall a dry drinking experience. This is extremely well balanced sake with hidden fresh flavors such as cherry, melon, pear and sweet rice on a flow that dances through the palate. Sakurabiyori gets softer in a larger glass and gets a little creamy as it warms. The low alcohol content makes this super sipping sake perfect for those who like dry, light and pristine sakes that have the feeling of drinking gorgeous water. WORD: Gentle WINE: Soft reds/Dry whites BEER: Light ales FOODS: Sushi and Sashimi for sure! Light fare with a hint of saltiness.

Fukucho Junmai Ginjo Nama Genshu.description: The nose on this seasonally released unpasteurized sake (sake is typically pasteurized twice for stability and preservation) is a fresh collection of grapes, blueberries, mango, and Jolly Rancher candy. A fresh and fun hot weather sake with a juicy fruit basket personality and a spritzy bright fluid. It is very lively and tingly and the sweetness is light and bright not heavy and loud. Look for pear, red apple, mango, and a pinch of ripe peach. A larger vessel distributes the action better, but if you want the lively tingle use a smaller cup. WORD: Juicy Wine: Bright reds/Fruity whites BEER: Fruit ales FOODS: Light clean hot weather fare, sashimi, fruit salads, crab salad.(2019)The nose on this “namazake” is a lively collection of green apple, white grape, and pear aromas. Have you ever tasted Moon On the Water that we carry year-round? It’s lush and fruity. So imagine this brew not being pasteurized? Say hello to a very lively and spritzy sake that jumps out of the glass and into your palate. Bright, zesty, snappy, and so much fun. It’s super fresh, and almost like drinking straight from the fermentation tank. This new style of effervescent sake is extremely popular, and it works so well on a hot day for a refreshing picnic pop. There are juicy fruit tones including apple and young pear, and a hint of banana, but it’s all about the joyous fizzle and shizzle! WORD: Lively WINE: Beaujolais/Fruity whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Champagne fare, cheese plates, fruit plates.(2018)

Gokyo Arabashiri Junmai Nama Genshu.description: The nose on this seasonally released unpasteurized sake is gentle collection of steamed rice, mint, tangerine, and melon aromas. Say hello to freshness in a glass. This brew was released without pasteurization to show you the brash, lively, zesty, tingly, and activeness of sake that is living and fresh. Look for bright flavors such as young pear, melon, apple, citrus, and a touch of honey tea. This brew is edgy because it is like a Beaujolais in that it is as fresh as it gets. And to think that this is only made with rice and water. It is semi-thick, semi-dry, and fully wicked. WORD: Alive WINE: Beaujolais/Crisp Whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Sushi, sashimi, shellfish, steamed fish. (2019)What a great nose on this unpasteurized seasonally released sake withlemongrass, strawberry and powdered sugar elements. Why drink namasake? This brew is the reason, because it drinks raw, bright, frisky, brash andabsolutely fresh! It is living and it drinks that way. Look for waves ofstrawberry, kiwi, powdered sugar, and persimmon flavors that dance on ajumpy fluid that zings through the palate. It’s fruity but the flavors dry up bythe long and splendid tail. A mid-size glass brings out more flavors and a wineglass sports a longer finish. This is free-run sake at its best! WORD: FreshWINE: zesty reds/bright whites BEER: crisp ales FOODS: International spice,fried foods, bright fresh cuisines. (2015)

Gokyo Hiyaoroshi Junmai Namazume.description: The nose on this seasonally released sake that was made for fall cuisines is a mild collection of cream, cereal, minerals, and banana bread aromas. Lots of fall draftsakes are heavy and rich, but Gokyo is different in that it drinks electric, bright, light and very fresh. It’s almost “rich lite” with tasty rice elements and an overall fluffy quality that billows through the palate. Smooth and grainy it has hidden tastes of honey coated nuts, butter, and banana muffin. As the fluid warms behold a nice French toast quality that shimmers in the glass and allows one to taste the water of the brew as well. WORD: Smokey WINE: Sharp Reds/Bright Whites BEER: Dry AlesFOODS: Seasonal seafood, smoked oysters, smoked fish and fowl, and cheeseboard. (2018)Hiyaoroshi sake are made in the winter and aged and released the next fall to pair well with autumn cuisine. This unique brew has a gentle nose of citrus, leather, butter, and cocoa aromas. Say hello to the most complex of our fall draft sake this season. This brew is would appeal to red wine drinkers who enjoy a tannin-like drinking experience with some astringency and flavors galore. Look for dried fruit, green apple, and young pear flavors that drink fat and frisky in the palate. The unique semi-sour flavor screams complexity with a vibrant tingle that is cherished by food pairing specialists. A larger glass lets all of the elements blend together for a great seasonally fresh flavor. WORD: Complex WINE: Tannin reds/Crisp Whites BEER: Sour ales FOODS: Seafood stews, pasta, hearty soups(2017)

Gokyo Summer Junmai Nama.description: The nose on this limited release summer unpasteurized sake is a gentle collection of green apple, melon, peach, and Jolly Rancher Candy. Finally! A summer sake that tastes like a summer sake that is refreshing, light, tingly, and fun. This brew is so enjoyable in a larger glass to bring out a lively smoothness that is fruity up front and dry in the finish. Look for dried fruit tones of apple, pear, apricot, and white peach. Light and tingly this summer sake is juicy and zesty, but so relaxed in the dry and crisp finish. The SMV is +2 but this Gokyo drinks more lively and frisky with far more brightness than a fat sweet brew. WORD: Refreshing WINE: Zesty reds/ Crisp whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Seafood, shellfish, oysters, citrus salads.

Harushika Shiboribana Junmai Ginjo Nama.description: The nose on this spring released seasonal sake is a subtle collection of white grapes, tangerine, and sweet rice aromas. Say hello to a very full and ripe Nama that has lots of Ginjo qualities and flavors. Look for pink grapefruit, white grape, and blood orange flavors on a fluid that is fat and chewy that has a little tingle, which means it’s still living! Very vivid with a very proud plumpness this brew has lots of glucose-like feelings with a dry finish. Fleshy and fun, this “Spring Deer” is a full-bodied Nama with bright citrus fruit tones on a juicy fluid that jumps. WORD: Citrus WINE: Fat Reds/Plump Whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: International spicy fare, grilled fare, fruit plates. (2019)The nose on this year’s Harushika Nama is a splendid collection of blueberry, green apple, honeydew, and bubble gum elements. Ha! Usually this sake drinks very much like a ginjo each season, but this year there is a lot more pop! Good stuff as drinking a nama should be like drinking a fresh and semi-brash version of its pasteurized self. Far less controlled and far more crisp look for young pear and apple tones on a juicy fluid that ends up on the dry side. And on a very interesting front this brew explodes in the front of the palate – the immediate palate, which is unique and fun as the crisp flow then leaves the back of the throat. Flavor up front with a dry crisp finish. You can’t ask more for a living brew than that! WORD: Crisp WINE: Dry Reds/Bright Whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Think international spice, salty and savory dishes. (2016)

Kamoizumi Aged Nama.description: This is straight up a “different sort of sake.” A two year-aged “fresh” sake doesn’t make sense, but the result is really a uniquely flavored brew that is extremely tasty and is an all-together different sake experience. The nose is a great collection of dried fruit, honey, citrus and musky elements. Fat and gooey this brew has a rich honey characteristic that speaks to after dinner drink fans. Is it complex or quaffable? Or is it both? Look for sweet honey, tangerine, and raisin flavors on a smokey fluid that is sort of a condensed nama flow. Port and Sherry fans rejoice! WORD: Rich WINE: Port/Sherry BEER: Sweet Ales FOODS: Meat and Game, hugely flavored fare, cheese plates and cigars! (2012)

Katafune Shiboritate Tokubetsu Honjozo N.description: The nose on this unpasteurized “Nama” sake is a full collection of pear, mineral, plum, veggie, and steamed rice aromas. Whoa! Stop the presses and call your dentist. This Nama version of a Trophy winning sake is like taking a walk through the candy store of your youth. Thick, rich, round, full-bodied this baby is sweet and luscious. It is a very pronounced Nama that is fat and chewy with loads of sugar-like flavors that drink velvety smooth with a candy shop sweetness. Look for simple syrup, rock candy, clear maple syrup, and sugar flavors in a flow that is not cloying just fat and full. If you like sweeter Nigori sake you will love this brew. If you have a sweet tooth you will love this brew. If you know sake complexity you will love this brew. WORD: Candy Shop WINE: Full Reds/Sweet Whites BEER: Sweet Belgians FOODS: International spice, cheese plates, champagne fare, dessert wine fare.

Kikusui Hiyaoroshi Junmai Ginjo Namazume.description: This is a seasonal released sake. Call True Sake at 415-355-9555 foravailability, size, and pricing.The nose on the specially released “seasonal draft sake” is a gentle collection of roasted nuts, wood, steamed rice, and straw aromas. This is not your mom’s Kikusui, so don’t let the familiar bottle trick you into thinking you will be sipping a light and slightly fruity Junmai Ginjo. This is better! Round and savory it hits you with the first sip as velvety, rich, and smooth characters come forth. The fluid is very chewy and is loaded with savory flavors such as amber honey, rich rice candy, honey nut breakfast cereal, and a hint of chocolate brownie as the fluid warms. This Hiyaoroshi is drinking very well this season and it is a food-pairing fiend. WORD: Rich WINE: Pinot Noir/Chewy whites BEER: Belgian Ales FOODS: Great for rich and savory fall dishes including your Thanksgiving dinner. (2018)The nose on this seasonally released Fall Draft sake is a gentle collection of crushed leaves, soy sauce, citrus, and toasted rice aromas. Okay! Hands down this is the softest and smoothest Hiyaoroshi sake this season. It is so round and fluffy you can actually taste the smoothness. That’s right! You can taste the feeling! On the whole the brew drinks dry with a velvety flow. There is a nice richness with all of the ricey and neutral flavors. I wrote “rich water” in my notes and feel that this is the definition of a rice libation. It’s not fruity or sweet, just ricey and nice!WORD:SmoothWINE:Merlot/soft whitesBEER:Creamy alesFOODS:Salty and savory fare with grease and oil. (2017)(2016) The nose on this single-pasteurized seasonal sake is made up of smoky, burnt rice, caramel, and earthy elements. Well this special sake is a great example of a different “expression” of a sake that you love. So many folks love the Kikusui JG for good reason, but behold a sake that is similar in elegance but different in complexion. This is an elegant Hiyaoroshi that drinks smooth and semi-rich with a flow that is velvety, silky and nice! Not as bright as the JG, this slightly aged sake has a little more rich sweetness that is mellow and well balanced. A smooth mouthful that is thick but clean, and holds hints of rice, caramel, nougat, and sweet bun flavors. WORD: Velvety WINE:Clean Reds/Fat Whites BEER: Clean ales FOODS: Rich flavors of the season.

Koshinohomare Shiboritate Junmai Nama Ge.description: The nose on this unpasteurized and undiluted (18%) spring released sake is a unique collection of rice candy, banana, strawberry, and mineral aromas. Semi-sweet and sunny, a perfect picnic sake that is bright and happiness in a glass. A very soft and smooth brew with a fluffy texture and lots of honey tones. Look for honeycomb, honey tea, and honey candy flavors that drink juicy and bright and leaves longs legs on the glass. Rich and full-bodied fun that is released in the spring to bring out a freshness and brashness of raw and living sake. A really good “feeling” sake that speaks to those who like candy licks and sweet rice tricks. A sake with a lot of weight to it! WORD: Juicy WINE: Lush Reds/Juicy Whites BEER: Sweet Ales FOODS: Curry, Salsa, International heat. (2019)The nose on this seasonally released “raw” or unpasteurized sake is a calm collection of plum, melon, peach, and floral aromas. Bingo! This year’s Junmai Genshu has a wonderful feeling and flavor combination and would speak to any sake drinker looking to tastes just brewed sake. Fresh and a little chippy it reminds the drinker that you are enjoying flavors such as apple, grape, and mango in 3D as this sake is not heated to preserve it. Smooth yet vast there is a very expansive action with each sip that brashly but not brutally sways the palate. It is fruit forward indeed, but there is also a gentle sweet rice richness that makes the brew drink with more expression. A very tasty performance this year! WORD: Expressive WINE: Round Reds/ Fruity whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Very food friendly focusing on elegant savory flavors, grilled bits, fresh seafood, and some international spice.(2017)This seasonally released sake is as fresh as fresh can be and has a nose filled with cooked rice, sweet nut, and banana crème brulee elements. Hello! Are you looking for a different flavored sake that is super tasty and super unique? Well look no further as this year’s version doesn’t taste like last year’s breakfast cereal bar, but rather it has a killer crème brulee attitude! Rich and vivid this unpasteurized sake is chewy, fat and very full-bodied. I wrote “round, ricy, and yummy” in my notes and I think that about does it! It is semi-sweet, but boarders more on rich sweet that is complex but very enjoyable. Round and expressive this brew makes for a great meal in a glass sake, and don’t let the 17%-18% alcohol fool you because you can’t even notice it with all of the fun flavors bouncing around. WORD: Crème Brulee WINE: Rich Reds/ Fat Whites BEER: Belgian Ales FOODS: The kitchen sink! SMV: +4 Acidity: 1.6(2016)

Makiri Draft Extra Dry Kimoto Junmai Gin.description: The nose on this seasonally released nama is filled with cherries, mineral water, and floral aromas. Hands down the driest nama to bless our shelves. If you like it dry and lively this brew is for you. Look for cooked rice, raspberry, and quince flavors on zesty flow that is sharp and cutting. It is semi-thick and juicy, but dry! How do they do that? It has dried trail mix fruit flavors that work better in a larger glass. WORD: Dry WINE: crisp reds/dry whites BEER: Tight Ales FOODS: Made for greasy fare!

Masumi Arabashiri Junmai Ginjo Nama.description: The nose on this very-old-friend-of-True-Sake has a great collection of cherry, grape, berry, sweet rice, and powder sugar aromas. Since you’ve had this brew before what’s it like this year? The ’19 version of Arabashiri is more controlled and smooth than in year’s past. It is smooth with round and rolling fruit tones that are juicy and soft, semi-thick, semi-rich and fully tasty. The larger the vessel the more zesty and fresh feeling with honeydew melon, pear, apple, and a hint of grapefruit. A mid-sized glass brings out the best flavor to feeling play, but whatever you drink out of you will taste fresh sake at its best. WORD: Fresh WINE: Brights Reds/Fruity Whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: International spice, sushi, sashimi, American sushi. (2019)Another great year for one of the most popular and longest standing exported nama sake in the business. The nose on “free run” unpasteurized sake is a collection of tangerine, melon, blueberry, and grape aromas. There are some sake that when you drink them it makes your mouth happy, and this nama is one of those. Semi-thick, frisky, brisk, and crisp this lively sake drinks as if you just pulled it from the fermenting tank. Loaded with tingly flavors of citrus, white grape, and young pear it is both fruity and floral. The Arabashiri 2018 is more bright than year’s past, which makes it more expressive in the glass. It is a touch sweeter in a small cup, and the acidity flows better in a wine glass. Fresh and fun is one thing! Fresh, fun, and joyous is quite another. WORD: Joyous WINE: Beaujolais/Crisp whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: The kitchen sink, especially if your kitchen as international spice! (2018)

Masumi Junmai Ginjo Hiyaoroshi.description: This is a seasonal released sake. Call True Sake at 415-355-9555 foravailability, size, and pricing.The nose on this specially released seasonal draft sake is a gentle collection of cinnamon, cream, roasted rice, earthy, and nutty aromas. Hiyaoroshi sake were made to be stored for a brief time to achieve a certain flavor point that goes well with fall cuisine flavors, which tend to be rich and savory. Round, smooth, clean this once pasteurized brew is very user-friendly that has a lightness to go with its richness. There is a Ginjo feeling that has hints of flan and is very slippery. Look for hints of sweet rice, caramel, crème brûlée, and a gentle creaminess that opens up as the sake warms in the glass. WORD: Clean WINE: Merlot/Soft whites BEER: Belgian Ales FOODS: Fall rich flavors from the grill and sauce pot.(2018)The nose on this seasonally released single pasteurized Fall Draft sake is a gentle collection of earthy, shroomy, ricey, and nougat aromas. This brew has gentle written all over it with gentle fluid, gentle flow, and gentle flavors abound. It is a very light sake that his semi-rich flavors of maple syrup, steamed rice, nougat, and honey. These rich flavors do better in a smaller glass, and as the fluid comes into room temperature. It is balanced and easy drinking and pairs with subtle autumn fare. WORD: Light WINE: Merlot/Soft Whites BEER: Light ales FOODS: Very subtle and clean flavors, steamed fish and chicken, sashimi.(2017)

Nechi Otokoyama Tokubetsu Honjozo Nama \.description: The nose on this unpasteurized sake that is made with “Estate” brewing rice, which means that they grow their own, is a very fresh collection of cucumber, powder sugar, rice candy, cocoa, and mineral aromas. Damn! This sake tastes like the bottle looks - light, cool, and minerally. What an awesome Nama. It is so light, bright, and refreshing but is loaded with really tasty flavors such as white grape, honeydew melon, blueberry, and tons of minerals like snowball melt. There is also a very unique vein of citrus tones such as tangerine, and grapefruit, with an added powder sugar touch. A fantastic drinking brew that has a 1.8 acidity level, and has an 18% alcohol level, which you cannot even tell that they’re there, so we will call it the “Crazy 8’s.” WORD: Snowmelt WINE: Light reds/Mineral Whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Oysters, shellfish, sashimi, poached fish. (2019)The nose on this unpasteurized seasonal sake is an array of yeasty, floral, and sugary aromas. Say hello to a sake that could very well be a breakfast brew as there are layers of berry fruit tones and a wonderful vein of honey. Plump, viscous, and chewy the legs on this sake are long and so too is the time in the palate. There is a peek-a-boo 18% alcohol content, but the smoothness and the balance of the brew disguises the elevated alcohol percentage. Using their own Gohyakumangoku made in the famous Nechi Valley you will be wowed by the richness of the rice and will revel in the layers of fruit forward flavors.WORD: HoneyWINE:Sweet reds/Fat whitesBEER:Sweet AlesFOODS:Great for large flavors including international spice. (2018)

Ohyama Hiyaoroshi Tokubetsu Junmai Namaz.description: The nose on this very limited fall draft sake is a mild collection of steamed wood, cooked cherries, and melon aromas. My first two comments when doing this review were “smooth and different!” I love that because I love sakes that are different and good. This is a very unique Hiyaoroshi sake, because it has such an interesting flavor spectrum from quince and blackberry to an amazing glimpse of persimmon. Yup! I typed that. Persimmon! It is sweet, but not too sweet. Round, semi-chewy and rich but it drinks light and confident. There is a very comfortable feeling in the palate like wearing a warm sweater on a cold day. A great exploration sake that has a very unique sweetness and a subtle anise tail. WORD: Persimmon WINE: Sweet reds/Full Whites BEER: Smooth Belgians FOODS: Rich and savory fall flavors with fowl, game, and fatty fish. (2018)Say hello to our first time Fall Draft from Ohyama! Hello! And we are very pleased to have this special brew as part of the fall single pastueirzed sake selections called Hiyaoroshi! It has a gentle nose of blueberry, grape and powdered sugar aromas. This draft is a little different then the other fall releases in that it is more on the fruity side with big bright fruit tones on a fun and lively fluid. There is a certain rich crispness that speaks to big white wine drinkers who like good acidity and good mouth feel that borders on zesty! There are mild tropical fruit elements and the overall feeling is enhanced when consumed out of a large white wine glass. Ohyama has some fruity brews in their line-up and me thinks this could be a single pasteurized version of one of those. It drinks fresh and more nama nama like then the other offerings and this makes it more shell fish, seafood and white meat friendly. WORD: Juicy WINE: Zesty reds/Frisky whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: See above! (2015)

Ohyama Tokubetsu Junmai Nama.description: 2018 - The nose on this summer released unpasteurized sake is a gentle collection of melon, grape, and sweet rice aromas. Get ready to chillax with “Big Mountain” this summer as this brew is far more gentle then in year’s past. It is a very round and smooth nama that one can almost say is easy on the palate. There are no sharp or jagged edges with this living sake, but that doesn’t mean that it is not bright. Chewy, smooth, juicy, and semi-dry there are hints of green apple and fresh pear with a very minerally over-all freshness. This is a very good introduction to unpasteurized sake, as it shows new flavor levels with a refreshing liveliness that isn’t brash or zesty. WORD: Gentle WINE: Soft reds/Minerally Whites BEER: Hefeweizen FOODS: Summer light fare, clean dishes, simple flavors.2017-The nose on this unpasteurized, seasonally released sake is an assembly of gentle green apple, candy, sweet rice, and hint of banana aromas. Say hello to one of the best summer sake in the business! This year’s version is very soft and semi-fat with mild fruit tones that drinks very velvety, round, and flavorful. It is super smooth with a little tingle that says “nama.” Round and chewy with pear tones, red apple, and apple pie! This summer, think more mild and more yummy. WORD: Smooth WINE: Merlot/soft whites BEER: Belgian ales. FOODS: Burgers, hot dogs and buns.

Otokoyama.description: This is a seasonal released sake. Call True Sake at 415-355-9555 foravailability, size, and pricing.The nose on this seasonally released fall draft sake is a combination of single pasteurization and the “Kimoto” or traditional polerammed style and has a fascinating bouquet of woody, creamy, ricey, and apple cider aromas. What’s not to love about harbor seals drinking wonderful fall sake with amazingly lovely leaves falling about? One of our favorite Hiyaoroshi labels on one of our favorite seasonal sake. This year’s version is clean, tight, and dry with roasted flavors of cooked fruit, toast, cinnamon, pasta, cocoa and a touch of young pear. Smoot, round, and soft it drinks very fast through the palate and as the fluid warms look for a hint of roasted vanilla. It drinks zesty and fun, and the overall impression is its dryness that the end of the sip. There is more body as the fluid warms. WORD: Dry WINE: Dry Reds/Crisp Whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Good for Autumn salty and savory cuisines. (2018)Gotta love a label with seals drinking sake in the Autumn leaves right? The nose on this fall nama is cool collection of cinnamon, toasted rice, and woody aromas. Say hello to one of the driest Hiyaoroshi sake this fall. Light, dry, and very flavorful this brew drinks almost like soft water. Look for hints of cinnamon and rice flavors that almost tastes like a breakfast cereal. Smooth and very slick the fluid is almost buoyant and it floats in the palate. A large glass makes the brew lighter, but the best flavor point is achieved with a smaller cup. When you warm this sake look for a malty and cocoa flavor. WORD: Cinnamon WINE: Dry Reds/Crisp Whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: This is a perfect fried food sake that takes oil well. (2017)(2015)Sake brewers in Japan make a special sake in the spring and release it in the fall to pair well with the wonderful autumn flavors in Japan. These sakes are called Hiyaoroshi and this particular version is very unique because it is “pole rammed” or uses the “Kimoto” method to produce it! The nose on this single pasteurized “draft” sake has hints of steamed rice, wet wood rice paddle, and actually smells like a sake brewery in the early morning. Say hello to a dry and clean sake that explores all the corners of a brew that is crisp, tight, and compact. It is a very quick through the palate sake that speaks to red wine drinkers who like a lot of tannins in their juice. Look for hints of dried rice, chestnuts, cedar, wheat and rice krispy flavors on a fluid that expands as it warms. Not only dry, but this brew is slick like wet water and feels layered in the palate like a martini. WORD: Dry WINE: Crisp reds/ tight whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Autumn Flavors!

Otokoyama Shiboritate Tokubetsu Junmai N.description: The nose on this spring released unpasteurized and undiluted (17%) sake is a fine collection of apple, melon, white grape, and snow mineral aromas. Okay folks! Have you ever wanted to taste a sake that is still in the fermentation tank? A living and breathing brew that is lively and active and brash? This is your chance, because this Nama drinks vivid, bright, zesty, crisp and dry. Look for grape, berry, melon, and young pear flavors with a hint of powdered sugar. Fresh, fun, crisp with lots of rice liveliness. This drinks as fun as the label on the bottle. WORD: Fresh WINE: Tight Reds/Crisp Whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Salty and savory bar fare, greasy and comfortable. (2019)Love the new label for this consistently great sake. The nose is a mild sample of green apple, cream, and steamed rice tones. My first two words written in muy notes were: Fun and Bright! Hells yes! This Genshu says hello with abundant fruit flavors of pear and apple that taste fresh and oh so seasonal. A little crisp with a little tingle it drinks fun because it wakens the pallet with a hint of tangy goodness wrapped in a bright fluid that sort of pops in your mouth. It tastes young and fun indeed! WORD: Fresh WINE: Crisp Reds/ Bright Whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: International spice, salty and savory, clean sashimi, sweetmeat shellfish, oysters. (2017)

Otokoyama Tokubetsu Junmai Nama.description: The nose on this summer released unpasteurized sake is splendid array of green apple, grasses, snow melt, and steamed rice aromas. This brew is a very classy summer nama that drinks cool and confidently fun. Light and dry with loads of “tip of the iceberg” flavors that keep showing more and more as the fluid warms in the glass. Very gentle nama zake that is smooth and clean with hints of pear, cantaloupe, and green apple Jolly Rancher flavors. It is a clever sake that appeals to dry sake drinkers, but has all the body and movement of a lower SMV brew. The label speaks volumes as this sake is pure summer fun with a ton of freshness and lots of flavor surprises. WORD: Clean WINE: Tight reds/ Fresh whites BEER: Crisp ales FOODS: Salty and savory fare good for the grill, sushi and sashimi.

Otokoyama Yukishibare.description: The nose on this super seasonal sake is a fresh collection melon, pear, powder sugar and green apple elements. Talk about a lively unpasteurized sake that is fit for the spring to sprung. Crisp in the glass look for flavors galore including young pear, peach, melon, and crisp apple tones. Fresh and brash with a minty tingle that almost turns into a tasty minerality as the fluid warms. This is a great flavored sake that looks misty in the bottle like a distant snow storm in the middle of Spring. WORD: Crisp WINE: Zesty reds / Frisky whites BEER: Crisp ales FOODS: International spice, grilled large flavors, frisky cuisines with attitude(2015)

Oze no Yukidoke Junmai Daiginjo Namazume.description: The nose on this Junmai Daiginjo Fall Draft sake is a gentle collection of steamed rice, plums, honey, and butter aromas. There aren’t many Daiginjo Hiyaoroshi sakes out there so it’s a good idea to try this very nice brew that is velvety, creamy, and layered. It drinks relaxed, but there is a freshness that lifts up the hints of mangos, honeydew, and cooked pear flavors. There are elements of tangy citrus and crisp cherry notes that float on the wide and juicy fluid that is smooth and very comfortable in the palate. A mid-sized glass enhances the drinking experience and if you dig deep enough look for a rich layer of raisins. A super cool fall draft that is as premium as Hiyaoroshi sake can get! WORD: Velvety WINE: Pinot Noir/Chewy Whites BEER: Honey Ales FOODS: Seasonally fresh fall flavors, especially fatty fish of colder waters. (2018)Say hello to one of our newest Hiyaoroshi or Fall single pasteurized draft sake. The nose on this very flavorful and bright seasonally released brew has hints of lemon honey, sweet nuts, and red apple aromas. Fun Fun Fun. This sake is so excitingly good. Sweet, round, and with a quick finish there are layers of smooth and bright flavors. Look for tangerine, pear, and apple flavors that roll through the palate. Juicy and fleshy fluid that explodes with white grape and pear elements as the sake warms in the glass. This sake screams Junmai Daiginjo. WORD: Bright WINE: Fruity reds/Fat whites BEER: Honey Ales FOODS: Sushi and Sashimi, steamed fish and light grilled chicken. (2017)

Oze no Yukidoke Natsugin Junmai Daiginjo.description: The nose on this seasonally released single-pasteurized sake is a juicy collection of grape, pear, and sweet rice aromas. Ok Folks! I personally bought a case of this exceptional brew because it drinks so fat, fun, and fancy! First of all, it is a Junmai Daiginjo that has been heated only once which makes the flavors blast off in the palate. Look for melon, pear, ripe apple, and rice dessert flavors on a fluid that is chewy and viscous and fills the mouth so well. The “impact” level is off the charts on this “Oze,” and you will notice your glass empties quickly. That’s the sign of a great sake, it disappears quickly! WORD: Impact WINE: Fruity Reds/ Fat Whites BEER: Thick Belgian Ales FOODS: Shellfish, American Sushi, cheese plates, Fruit salads

Rihaku Omachi Junmai Ginjo Nama Genshu.description: The nose on this very complex seasonally released brew is a tricky collection of oatmeal, persimmon, and sweet rice aromas. It’s immediately apparent on your first sip that this Nama is not like the others. Is it the Omachi rice? Is it the Genshu factor? Is it the way this great brewery builds their sake? Or is it a little of all of the above? Smooth, chewy, round and very flavorful this brew appeals to complex wine drinkers who like finding a story within the fluid. Look for kiwi, green grapes, tangy citrus elements like a little lemon custard. It is a very solid and confident sake that feels right in the glass and palate, and is definitely the road less taken! WORD: Complex WINE: Huge reds/ Citrus-like whites BEER: Sour ales FOODS: Complex fare with soups and pasta, meats and game. (2019)The nose on this seasonally released sake is a very interesting collection of rice, yeast, bread, and oatmeal aromas. This is a very smooth and round nama that has a very understated complexity. Soft, round, and rich there is a nice long tail with a touch of a sour element similar to a sourdough bread. There is a gentle astringency that the Japanese call “Shibumi” that also has a peek-a-boo peach tone. The richness is not heavy, but it drinks smooth and very Omachi-like. And best of all this savory sake is a great food pairing monster. WORD: Velvet (hammer) WINE: Pinot Noir / Meaty Whites BEER: Sour Ales FOODS: The kitchen sink! Anything salty and savory. Anything from the grill. (2018)

Seikyo Omachi Junmai Ginjo Nama.description: This is a seasonal released sake. Call True Sake at 415-355-9555 foravailability, size, and pricing.The nose on this unpasteurized summer sake is a gentle collection of green apple, cut grasses, rose water, and berry aromas. Say hello to a nama sake made with the Omachi brewing rice varietal, which is one of our favorites! Chewy, bright, lush, large, velvety, lively, vivid, this brew drinks fresh as can be. Look for apple, sweet rice, mango, and pear flavors that jump on a bright and layered flow. This is nama sake personified. It is also a nama that actually does well warming in the glass. A little lighter in nature than 2017, but full of vivid fun that makes drinking juicy and flavorful sake so much fun. It is alive and expressive and you can’t beat that! WORD: Bright WINE: Large reds/ Zesty whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: The kitchen sink!(2018)The nose on this seasonally released unpasteurized sake is one of the great reminders to smell your sakes people – what a nose filled with grassy, grainy, green grape, melon and fruit tones. If the color green were to have an aroma this sake would be it. This brew is one of those truly amazing sakes that is both fruity and grainy, but neither drinks sweet nor too dry. A big and tasty sake that is fat and fun and loaded with attitude and wonderful flavors such as kiwi, blueberry, melon, grape, and breakfast cereal. Omachi is a vintage rice varietal and you can taste its unique flavor in this sake, which is flavor forward with a hint of a tail. If you like sakes with personality plus then this nama is your cup of tea, but I recommend a larger glass to bring out more acidity and far more flavors. WORD: Tasty WINE: Big reds with tingle/Zesty Whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Very food friendly with spicy fare, veggies, seafood, and off the grill savories.

Shichi Hon Yari Junmai Nama Genshu.description: This is a seasonal released sake. Call True Sake at 415-355-9555 foravailability, size, and pricing.The nose on this specially released Spring Nama sake is a cool collection of green apple, steamed rice, pear, wax Halloween teeth, and Jolly Rancher candy. Talk about a “Discovery Sake”! This brew is so unique and so tasty it should be tried at least once by all unpasteurized sake lovers. Behold a “Green” brew that is all things green – green bottle, green apple, green young pear and mango flavors, and green sheen of freshly pressed nama sake. It is very expressive and very different. There is a great acidity play that mingles with the astringency of the sake, which gives it a vivid, tangy, and lively brew that would appeal to tannin-loving red wine drinkers. WORD: Green WINE: Tannin Reds/Tangy Whites BEER: Tangy Ales FOODS: Big red wine fare with complexity and depth, spice, and fried food.

Shichi Hon Yari Junmai Namazume Hiyaoros.description: This is a seasonal released sake. Call True Sake at 415-355-9555 foravailability, size, and pricing.This exceptional fall draft seasonally released sake has a wonderful nose filled with nutty, ricey, toasty, earthy, and a touch of cooked apple aromas. Say hello to a really fantastic Hiyaoroshi sake that has a magic flavor that puts a smile on your Autumn face. It is liquid happiness in a glass that is smooth, rich and very expansive. Full-bodied it is layered with cooked pear flavors that are very pie-like. So think cooked pear or apple pie with hints of cedar and a mild tartness that plays so well with the acidity of the sweetness. This brew warms very nicely as even more flavors come forth. Truly a uniquely flavored sake that is basically Autumn in a bottle. WORD: Apple Pie WINE: Soft Reds/Fruity Whites BEER: Clean ales FOODS: Fall cuisine (2018)The nose on this Fall Draft sake has rice, raisin, dried plum, and wheat aromas. Say hello to the beefiest of this year’s Hiyaoroshi or single pasteurized sakes of this season. Round, soft, and very rich this sake drinks gooey and plump. Talk about chewing through a glass of sake this brew is full-bodied personified. There are hints of pancake or waffle qualities that drinks toasty and full. This brew drinks almost gamey, so it is perfect for full bodied fall cuisine flavors. WORD: Beefy WINE: Deep Reds/Huge Whites BEER: Stouts FOODS: Beef, game, and wildfowl. (2017)

Shichida Hiyaoroshi Omachi Junmai.description: The nose on this sake that is made in the winter, but released in the fall is a vivid collection of nougat, cream, marshmallow, canned corn, and cinnamon aromas. This is a very expressive and wide “Hiyaoroshi” sake that sings Autumn with rich rice and nougat flavors that pair so well with fall foods. Rich, savory, and alive there is a lot of umami in each layered sip. Look out for hints of cream, nougat, candy corn, cereal, caramel, and a hint of cinnamon. As Mei said, “It drinks like fall pies.” The strength of the brew is it’s bold richness (Omachi rice milled to 75%) on a fluid that expands in the palate. A mid size glass brings out the most flavor, and as the fluid warms the richness increases. WORD: Rich WINE: Deep Reds/Rich Whites BEER: Large Belgian Ales FOODS: Rich fall cuisines, meats, game, fowl, fatty fish.

Shichida Junmai Ginjo Muroka Nama.description: It’s Spring Nama Season and the nose on this unpasteurized beauty is a unique collection of grapefruit, peach, lemon peel, and steamed rice aromas. Talk about a big, sweet, and sexy nama! This non-charcoal-filtered (Muroka) sake is not a Nigori, but it drinks similar to one. It is a very full-bodied brew with a “gotcha” first sip. The sweetness is more bright than sweet with a gentle acidity play. Chewy, layered, and really fun in the glass. Look for honeydew melon, ripe pear, and peach compote flavors that drink semi-sweet upfront, but finish balanced and very tasty. WORD: Honey WINE: Chewy Reds/Fat Whites BEER: Sweet Ales FOODS: International Spice from tacos to curry, American sushi, and large pastas.(2019)Not a lot of Saga sake is available in the US, but this brewery is a great representative of sake from that region. With a powerhouse nose of plums, grapes, sweet beets, and sweet rice aromas this “raw” sake is a party in your glass. It’s a big party as it is crazy bright and very frisky. There is a lot of tingle in each sip, which makes for a refreshing, lively, and edgy drinking experience. A very nice assortment of crispy apple, tight pear, and young mango flavors with a vein of grape and dried fruits. It is an exciting fluid that is brisk, brash and darn near electric. I wrote “tingle time” in my notes and I was very impressed with how the flavor and feeling of this brew jumps right out of the glass. WORD: Bright WINE: Hot reds/Crisp whites BEER: Crisp ales FOODS: This big brew can dance with every food partner, stick to bigger (2018)

Shichida Natsu Junmai Nama.description: The nose on this summer released seasonal sake is a gentle collection of grapes, white pepper, floral, and candy aromas. This is a fun summer brew that knows what to do! It knows to drink light and bright with a tingle of sunshine zest. This is liquid summer in a bottle with juicy light flavors of anise, melon, and minerals on a dry fluid that is not bulky or beefy. Snappy, crisp, zesty, and lively it is fruity but with a solid dryness that speaks to those who like their tannin wines. It is a lower alcohol sake at 14%, but this doesn’t impact its wonderful flavor field. Light and confident this nama is perfect for picnics and sunshine at the beach. WORD: Summer WINE: Smooth reds/Thin Whites BEER: Soft Ales FOODS: Light summer fare that is not saucy or heavy, grilled fish and shrimp. 2017 - This elegant summer released unpasteurized sake has a gentle nose filled with green apple, grape, melon, and peach aromas. Talk about a gentle and soft sake that tastes so refreshing in the heat of summer. With a lower alcohol content of 14% this nama drinks round, smooth, and juicy. Your glass instantly becomes slippery goodness with hints of blueberry and apple flavors that are clean and subtle with a nice balance. This is the perfect day time sake for a hot picnic. WORD: Elegant WINE: Gentle reds/Creamy whites BEER: Light beers FOODS: Very clean cuisine.

Shirataki Jozen Junmai Daiginjo Genshu R.description: This amazing “Year of The Rooster” sake has wonderful nose filled with candy, grape, blueberry, and rose water aromas. Talk about a celebration in the palate! This stunning Daiginjo Genshu is one of those sakes that leaves you speechless when trying to explain how rice and water only can taste like a vibrant fruit plate. How do they do it? So smooth and yet so juicy, this brew “Wows” you with each sip. It’s viscous and chewy, but velvety and round and there is a very special fruity tail. Look for fleshy licks of pear, grape, blueberry and tropical fruit tones that turn to honey as the fluid warms in the mouth. Wine lovers take note of a rice sake that acts like wine in so many capacities, but boldly states I am a starch so pair with me accordingly! WORD: Fruity WINE: Smooth Reds/ Fat Whites BEER: Honey ales FOODS: So good on its own, but full enough to go with clean seafood and shellfish. Cheese and fruit plates. (2017)   Junmai Ginjo Nama Genshu. SMV: +3 Acidity: 1.6 The nose on this seasonally released nama from a great brewery in Niigata is filled with cherry, melon, and yeasty elements. Talk about a “live” smooth operator! This full figured brew from a kura that makes light and dry ginjo sake is a walk on the wild, bold, and punchy side. It’s like drinking Jozen Junmai Ginjo on steroids, but with a elegance and complexity that is really drinkable. There are dry fruit flavors such as honeydew melon that compliment the over-all dry ricy feel. Think soft, fluffy, weighty, and a little tingly pop on a proudly smooth fluid. So dry and clean you won’t even notice the 17.5% alcohol elegant punch. WORD: Smooth Wine: Dry reds/Fat crisp whites BEER: crisp ales FOODS: Anything from the ocean or grill and some international spice.(2016)

Shirataki Jozen Junmai Ginjo Hiyaoroshi.description: The nose on this seasonally released single pasteurized sake is a cool collection of cherry, flinty, melon, vanilla, and cream aromas. Talk about a fresh and fun seasonal sake. This Hiyaoroshi is bright, rich, and clever and ages very well in the bottle. It is juicy, lively and snappy, which differs a little to most rich fall brews. Lots of minerality to go with dried fruit tones such as cherry and cranberry with ripe melon. Layered and very refreshing this brew has a good attitude that does better in a wine glass. There is an undercurrent of richness, but the vividness of the brew masks the heaviness, which makes it lighter and brighter. WORD: Bright WINE: Crisp Reds/Flinty Whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Sushi, sashimi, cooked fish, shellfish, bright flavors. (Winter 2018)The nose on this seasonally released single pasteurized “draft” sake is a floral collection of citrus, ginger, and fruity aromas. Chewy, fat, gooey, and bright this Fall sake drinks smooth and very velvety. There are buckets of fruit tones all over the place. Look for grape, pear, apple, mango, and star fruit flavors that swim around on the juicy flow that is bright and rich! There is a rice sweetness as well, but the brew drinks more vivid than sweet. This is one of the brightest and fruitiest Fall Draft sake this season, and if you’re into slippery sake that are super flavorful then this brew is for you. WORD: Bright WINE: Zesty Reds/Fruity Whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Seasonal Crab and Shellfish, Oysters, Grilled Fish. (Winter 2017)2016 The nose on this seasonally released single-pasteurized sake is a great collection of blackberry, steamed rice, and apricot aromas. Talk about a supremely smooth Hiyoaroshi sake that drinks rich but clean with layers and layers of flavors on a round flow that feels great on the palate. It’s soft and lush with a gentle sweetness that is more rich and smooth than sweet. Look for apricot, cooked pears, and a fruit compote feeling that drinks chewy and viscous with a back door nuttiness. One of the best Fall Draft sake to hit these shores in years! WORD: Smooth WINE: Pinot Noir BEER: Creamy Ales.FOODS: Flavors of the fall!

Takachiyo 59 Chapter III Aimachi Junami.description: The nose on this extremely fresh sake is a great collection of strawberry, sweet rice, mango, and berry gum elements. Bright, fresh, and snappy this living sake drinks juicy, fleshy, and zesty. Look for fun fruit compote flavors such as strawberry, mango, and blackberry hints that jump around on the brash and sassy flow. The amazing thing is that for all of this upfront zest and fun the finish is quick and gone. This Chapter 3 has a lot of wine-like elements that are common with brews made with the 1801 yeast.WORD:BrightWINE:Fruity Reds/Crisp WhitesBEER:Crisp AlesFOODS:Fresh fare, fruit plates, cheese plates.(2019)The nose on this very interesting sake is a tight collection of apple, melon, oatmeal, and berry aromas. Takachiyo sakes were imported in limited quantities to determine if the western market likes them. The brewers make ultra popular sakes that are almost “cultish” in Japan within the sake drinking market. So they looked to the US, and to True Sake to determine if US drinkers like their style. I’m thinking tannin loving red wine drinkers will love this “Chapter III” which has a blend of two rice varietal, Aiyama and Omachi. It is crisp, tangy, zesty, and very bright in the glass. There are peek-a-boo citrus elements of tangerine and other dried fruit tones, but the overall drinking experience is compact and dry. There is some astringency at play and fans of the Japanese term Shibumi would enjoy greatly. There is a lot of bright complexity with this sake. WORD: Dry WINE: Tannin Reds/Crisp whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Shellfish, oysters, sushi, sashimi. (2018)

Takachiyo 59 Chapter One Ipponjime Junma.description: The nose on this special sake that is Nama Muroka is a unique collection of melon, pear, cucumber, and Asian Apple Pear aromas. Say hello to a fresh and gentle brew that drinks round and smooth with hints of citrus and other notes such as blueberry, Asian apple pear, and sweet rice. Zesty, bright, and crisp the flow is semi-chewy with a dry finish. Fresh and tight the Ipponjime definitely has a subtle peek-a-boo sour quality that drinks like tangerine, pink grapefruit, and “lemoncello” water. It’s pretty cool and refreshing, and a larger glass makes the experience smoother and softer. This is very gentle Nama Nama sake.WORD:CitrusWINE:Tight Reds/Crisp WhitesBEER:Crisp AlesFOODS:Sushi, sashimi, lightly grilled fare, shellfish.

Takachiyo 59 Chapter Two Aiyama Junmai G.description: The nose on this “exclusive to True Sake” Nama is a very mild collection of rice, tomato water, mint, and sunflower aromas. Say hello to a savory and dry unpasteurized brew that is bright, semi-zesty, and tight. This is a very clean Nama that has a unique dryness that is almost tannin-like with a very quick finish. There are neutral flavors of dried fruit tones similar to trail mix and rice cracker tones that drink very clean and dry. Dig deep enough and you can pull dry cranberry elements with a mineral water finish. A savory brew that is unique for an 1801 yeast, which makes this Aiyama Chapter very fun to explore.WORD:DryWINE:Dry reds/Crisp WhitesBEER:Dry Ales.FOODS:Salty and savory grilled fare. (2019)The nose on this “trail basis” sake is a great collection of apple, sugar cane, ripe fruit, and floral aromas. These Takachiyo sake were imported in limited quantities to determine if the western market likes them. The brewers make ultra popular sakes that are almost “cultish” in Japan within the sake drinking market. So they looked to the US, and to True Sake to determine if US drinkers like their style. And I’m betting hell yes! This sake called Chapter Two is made with a rice varietal called Aiyama and it is a very vivid and lively sake that is bright and wine-like with fruit tones galore and very light in the palate. Light and bright and dances in the palate with hints of granny smith apple, pear, and pineapple and a sweet finish. A perfect daytime sake that is fun to look at and more fun to drink. WORD: Tingly WINE: Beaujolais/ Fruity whites BEER: Fresh ales FOODS: Champagne fare, cheese and fruit plates.(2018)

Takachiyo 59 Hanafubuki Junmai Ginjo Mur.description: This next sake from Takachiyo, which makes sakes exactly the same way except for using a different rice varietal, has a lively nose filled with strawberry, vanilla, sugared nuts, and grape aromas. No. 4 is zesty, bright, brash and very lively like a fresh unpasteurized sake. It is loaded with creamy and tart flavors that jump around on the crisp flow. Look for hints of citrus, ripe peach, strawberry, plums and cooked cherries. Sounds like a lot and it is, and that’s what makes these sakes special. They have so many levels and layers to play with. The Hanafubuki rice makes this version drink very lively and very fun. WORD: Bright WINE: Zesty Reds/Acidic Whites BEER: Zesty AlesFOODS: More for drinking exploration but would handle spice, large complex flavors, and cheese plates.

Takachiyo 59 Omachi Junmai Ginjo Muroka.description: The nose on this extremely cultish sake is a fun collection of pear, melon, veggie, and rain water aromas. Juicy, bright, crisp, spritzy, and rich. This unpasteurized brew is a whirlwind of flavor and feeling in your glass. Look for layers of melon, cooked pear, and honey licks that are buoyed by a vein of richness. Drinks bright and juicy rather than bulky and cloying. The Omachi rice varietal gives this Chapter a solidness or richness that speaks to those who like bigger bolder flavors. But, the sneaky aspect of this brew is that the richness is fun not overbearing. WORD: Honey WINE: Fruity Reds/Rich Whites BEER: Honey Ales FOODS: Champagne fare, sushi, fruit plates, cheese plates. The nose on the this sake, which is part of a series that can only be found outside of Japan at True Sake, has a unique nose filled with roasted rice, toasted wheat bread, corn, cream, and yeasty rice aromas. No. 7 is rich, round, expansive, and savory. Be on the look out for very rich and solid flavors such as marshmallow, sourdough bread, sushi rice, and very ripe apricot. This is a beefy sake with meaty and rich action all over the place. There is a refreshing astringency play (Shibumi) that brings all of the roasted and full-bodied flavors together. The strength of this “Chapter” is the undying richness that can almost be described as a reduction in cooking terms. The Omachi rice varietal manifests itself in the richness and solid like nature of this full-bodied nama sake. WORD: Solid WINE: Huge Reds/Vast Whites BEER: Stouts FOODS: More for drinking exploration, but would work wonders with steak, steak, steak! (2018)

Tsukasabotan Senchu Hassaku.description: The nose on this seasonally released summer unpasteurized sake is a very unique collection of mineral, tomato water, and herbaceous aromas. Say hello to a nice summer nama that is full in flavor and zesty in feeling. It’s lively and fun and drinks with more weight and presence than last year. Smooth, chewy, bright, and chippy it is the driest of the summer namas, but doesn’t drink bone dry and thin. There are hints of melon, peach, and pear that drink more like dried versions rather than fresh and fruity. There is a great acidity play makes for more “sip action’ with a clean finish. An impact sake that drinks with more smoothness than bite. WORD: Dry WINE: Soft reds/Flinty whites BEER: IPA FOODS: Summer grilling fare from veggies and fish to burgers and dogs.

Urakasumi Hiyaoroshi Tokubetsu Junmai Na.description: This is a seasonal released sake. Call True Sake at 415-355-9555 foravailability, size, and pricing. The nose on this very familiar (tenth season at True Sake) fall draft sake is a gentle collection of roasted rice, honey, butter, and graham cracker aromas. This sake was made in the winter to specifically go with autumn flavors in Japan and elsewherearound the world. Crafted to meet a “feeling” as much as a flavor this year’s Urakasumi Hiyaoroshi is round and rich with a full-bodied attitude that actually drinks lighter and brighter than one would expect. It is very smooth with some tannin-like drying qualities and layers of subtle flavors such as cinnamon toast, cocoa, and a nice coffee hint as the fluid warms in the glass. But what makes this sake special is the creaminess found within each sip. And who doesn’t like creamy and savory flavors in the fall? WORD: Creamy WINE: Pinot Noir/Plump ChardsBEER: Creamy Ales FOODS: Rich and flavorful autumn cuisines, soups, stews, game, and seasonal bird. (2018)Year in and year out this is one of the most popular fall draft sake. The nose on the this seasonally released sake is a collection of brown sugar, breakfast cereal, and “brewery” smell with wet wood aromas. Similar to 2016 this year’s Urakasumi is the classic RSRS (Round, Soft, Rich, Smooth). Talk about a full-bodied expansive sake with gentle acidity and sold balance. Look for Nougat, oatmeal, and buttery flavors that drink like a candy-bar treat. Creamy and savory, viscous and fun, this brew is a fan favorite for a reason. WORD: Rich WINE: Pinot Noir/Chewy whites BEER: Belgian Ales FOODS: Creamy and savory fare, shellfish, oysters.(2017)(2016)The nose on this famous Fall Draft sake is a collection of caramel, raisin, maple syrup, and creamy butter aromas. This sake was one of the first Hiyaoroshi single pasteurized Fall released sake that was exported to the US. And for good reason! For years this brew has defined the flavors of the autumn season. Dryer than previous releases this brew has a crispness and zesty play on the rich and creamy flavors. Look for hints of caramel, cream, sweet rice on a tight and compact fluid. A very fresh and dry fall sake that expands in the glass as the fluid warms. Try heating it for food pairings! WORD: Crisp Wine: Big zesty reds/ crisp whites BEER: Crisp tight ales FOOD: Fall fatty flavors, comfort foods, rich oily fare.

Wakatake Onikoroshi Akino Ki-Ippon Hiyao.description: This is a seasonal released sake. Call True Sake at 415-355-9555 foravailability, size, and pricing. The nose on this fall released season single pasteurized sake has a gentle collection of steamed rice, crushed leaves, balsa wood, and grain tones. Hello! The Wakatake “Hiyaoroshi” 2015 is drinking great! In year’s past this brew tended to be very dry and very thin, but this year’s version has a new smoothness to complement its gentle dryness. It’s as if the fluid has more fluid to it, more juicy, more round, more layers, and more more! There hints of white peach, green grapes and very subtle vein of banana and the brew drinks far more fluffy as it comes to room temp. A mid-sized glass brings forth more feeling and flavor! Rich, smooth, silky and round with a tempting dryness that begs for food pairings! WORD: Smooth WINE: Pinot Noir/White Burgundy BEER: Round ales FOODS: Fresh fall cuisines!(2015)

Wakatake Oniotome Sachi Hiyaoroshi Tokub.description: The nose on this seasonally released Fall draft sake is made up of crushed leaves, steamed rice, and wood aromas. This great looking label artwork sake drinks more masculine than the lovely lady. Dry and roasty, round and smooth this is a very rich and savory brew. Talk about a sake that feels great in the mouth. It’s plump and viscous, which means chewy goodness. There are hints of nougat, dried apple, and raisin bread flavors all on a smooth and fat fluid. WORD: Savory WINE: Pinot Noir/Fat whites BEER: Belgian Ales FOODS: Salty and savory fare with oils and spice.

Wataribune Junmai Ginjo Nama.description: This is a seasonal released sake. Call True Sake at 415-355-9555 foravailability, size, and pricing.Beau promises he'll review this as soon as possible and we guarantee that it's a great sake. If you're here to order it because you've had it before and really liked it, you can beat Beau to the punch and review it first!

Akishika Okarakuchi Muroka Nama Genshu.description: 1.8L sizing is available by special order.Please call us at 415-355-9555 for more information.The nose on this crazy dry sake is filled with dried fruit, wet wood, cocoa, and vanilla aromas. Pretty much this is now the driest sake in the store and it’s unpasteurized to boot. Go figure! For all you fans of really bone dry sakes, this brew takes the cake with a super quick fluid that is loaded with rice tones. Not only dry this sake has an alcohol content of 19.5% that speaks to clear liquor drinkers and foodies who like taking the oil out of dishes. A mid-sized glass is a better vessel to capture the unique flavors and enhances the dryness without poking a stick at the very high acidity. Crisp, tight, and compact this sake sings the tune of dryness. WORD: Ultra Dry WINE: Dry reds/Crisp whites BEER: Crisp ales, IPA FOODS: Salty savory fare that needs the salt to subside.

Amabuki Himawari Junmai Ginjo Nama.description: This “nama” or “unpasteurized” sake (Typically sake is heated – pasteurized – twice as the preservative mechanism) has an interesting nose filled with base aromas such as brown grass, corn, honey and of course sunflower! Why “Of course” sunflower? Amabuki is a brewery known for using fun and new yeasts made from flowers and fruits, and this particular brew is made from sunflower yeast. Yes indeed! The result is a very intruiging sake that has layers and layers of flavors not typically found in the sake world. Look for starchy corn tones with hints of sweet potato and “of course” sunflower seed elements. Sake is a starch of course! There is also a unique sweet vein that gets lost in a larger vessel, but the soft, smooth and lush fluid does best with a nice chill. WORD: Sunflower WINE: Big reds/Dry whites BEER: Pilsners FOODS: Salty, savory, grilled fare with oils and saltiness.

Amabuki Ichigo Junmai Ginjo Nama.description: The nose on this unpasteurized or raw sake is a collection of strawberry, pear, honey, floral and of course strawberry aromas. Why "of course strawberry"? -because this brewery is known for making outstanding sakes using flower and fruit yeasts. And in this case the yeast comes from strawberries, which creates a very fruit forward sake that drinks soft, juicy and fun! But don't be mistaken as this smooth brew does not drink sweet, rather it has layers of fruit tones and "of course" ends with a very nice long strawberry tail. A larger glass brings forth more of a wine-drinking experience and this strawberry does better chilled. WORD: Strawberry WINE: Fruity Reds and Sweet Whites BEER: Fruity Ales FOODS: Salads, fruit dishes, international spicy fare.

Born Muroka Nama Genshu.description: The nose on this unpasteurized Daiginjo (not many of these) is made up of rose pedals, cooked banana, leather, tropical fruit, and steamy night elements. This is a really plump and viscous Nama that is both smooth and soft. There are a ton of ripe flavors to choose from honeydew melon wrapped in proscuitto, to a sweet fruit compote, to honeycomb. Juicy and fruity and so darn lively - so much flavor and so little back! The overall celebration of this sake is the every allusive "umami" quality, which is so present that they put a sticker on the bottle that says "umami." Rolling, fruity and soft like a sweet avocado! WORD: Umami WINE: Nouveau Beaujolais BEER: Sweet ales FOODS: White fish in a rich soy sauce, avocado salad, grilled oily fish, tofu.

DEN Junmai Nama.description: DEN Batch #6The nose on the sixth offering from this great little local brewery is a collection of green apple, rice, ginger, lemon peel, and pear aromas. This is a very lively and brash batch with lots of crisp fruit tones and a zesty acidity play. A bright brew with a quick drying finish that tingles and teases a long tail. Look for young peach, young pear, and dry apple flavors that dance with the brash and lively zesty qualities of this DEN Batch #6. More fruit tones come forth as the fluid warms in the glass, and a larger glass like a wine glass works best. WORD: Lively WINE: Frisky Reds/Brash Whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Sushi, sashimi, poke, grilled fare including vegetables, fish, chicken, and beef.

Dewazakura Dewasansan.description: Unpasteurized and undiluted this Ginjo has a full nose of ripe berries and Sweet Tarts. Primal Strength starts brilliantly with a rush of fruit flavors that sticks to the front teeth, a soft middle mouth and a hush for an ending. It is very well balanced despite being quite a complex brew with a sneaky acidity and possessing of a super fresh viscosity. This is a nama best acknowledged by sake drinkers with a lust for big flavors tied up neatly into pristine a packages that comes fresh pressed from the vat. WORD: Brisk WINE: Pinot Griggio/Zins/Big Cabs BEER: Spicy Pilsners FOODS: Spicy foods, grilled eel, chili shrimp.

Hakkaisan Shiboritate Nama Genshu.description: The nose on this “nama” or unpasteurized sake is a gentle collection of strawberry, melon, and floral tones. In the sake world it is a pretty amazing trick to get a 19% alc brew to drink smooth, balanced and even but the makers from Hakkaisan did a great job. This juicy and plump sake is loaded with velvety fruit flavors that do not drink sweet, rather they drink lush and solid. It is a great feeling sake that does wonders in the palate. If you want a glass full of fun then open this bottle and enjoy a fresh and controlled nama sake. WORD: Juicy WINE: Beaujolais BEER: Big ales FOODS: Anything from the ocean and fields!

Hatsumomiji Harada.description: The nose on this amazing sake with a new label is loaded with cherry, strawberry, melon, and floral aromas. Full and velvety with a killer finish this sake is one of those brews that you must try! Thick, round, full-bodied, plump, and smooth this not charcoal filtered sake lets it all hang out, and the result is delicious. My notes read, “So much flavor with a great dry finish.” The immense flavor field shows elements of sweet rice, berry, pear, and mango tastes. This brew is velvet personified and a glorious honey tone comes forth as the fluid warms in the glass. WORD: Brilliant WINE: Complex Reds/Deep Whites BEER: Full Ales FOODS: The kitchen sink from international spice to goose liver pate.

Houraisen Wa Aged Junmai Ginjo Nama \u2.description: The nose on this 12-month aged unpasteurized sake is a gentle collection of peach, apple, plum, red apple, and blueberry aromas. Why age a Nama sake? To get a feeling and flavor profile such as this Junmai Ginjo. Instead of being jagged, edgy, and brash the aging of this Nama creates a more comfortable feeling of the fluid. It helps the flavors meld better to produce a juicy yet smooth and round brew that is like a mellow Junmai Ginjo. Look for hints of green apple, grapes, blueberry and lots of pear as it warms in the glass. Milled to 50% this is actually like an unpasteurized Daiginjo, which makes the drinking experience all the more ethereal. This Nama is not bulky or sweet it is smooth and in the grove. WORD: Juicy WINE: Merlot/Soft Whites BEER: Soft ales FOODS: Great for grilled fare from chicken and fish to burgers and chops!

Ichinokura Hyakkoi Junmai Nama.description: The nose on this year-round unpasteurized sake is a fun collection of green apple, ricey, honeycomb, and nutty aromas. My notes read: A very cool Nama! It’s not fruity, not spastic, not jagged, rather it’s a very well-balanced and controlled unpasteurized brew that is ricey and savory and totally tasty! That made me laugh when I typed it up. Why? Because this sake is excellent and I forgot that. Clean, round and full-bodied which is soft in the mouth and has a light layer of sweetness. This brew has good body! It is balance personified for a Nama sake. Rice freshness! Hints of green apple, yeast, toasted wheat, and steamed rice. It is also very savory! Huh? Yup, it is rich and filled with umami goodness, which makes it un-fruity! WORD: Ricey WINE: Deep Reds/Rich Whites BEER: Big Belgians FOODS: Super food friendly with salty and savory, rich, and comfort cuisines.

Kameizumi Junmai Ginjo Nama Genshu CEL-2.description: The nose on this unpasteurized “Nama” sake is a fruity collection of apple, pear, melon, mango, and floral aromas. File this living and breathing raw sake under the title of “Juicy Plus.” Lively, juicy, fruity, lush, and fat; this brew has a ton of mouth feel to go with a ton of fruity flavors. Look for melon, mango, apple and sweet rice flavors that are pushed along by a chewy and dramatic flow. It is full-bodied and fun, and is actually a genshu at only 14% alc, which gives it that fat puffiness. A great sake to play with in the zone of how can rice and water taste like so many fruit tones. It is so dramatic, but is still so round and soft. There is a slight tingle of effervescence that proves this baby is living in your glass. WORD: Lush WINE: Fruity Reds/Fat Whites BEER: Fruity Ales FOODS: International spicy fare, fruit and cheese plates, American sushi and rolls.

Kikusui Funaguchi.description: All four of these sakes are pretty similar, but each has unique qualities. The nose on Red is ricy, tangy and yeasty. This “can” has been aged for one year and that mellows the brew done a bit. It’s not as brash as Gold and Green, and has a more pronounced sweetness that is softer and less rich. It drinks more easy than the others and has a nectar, honey, and fruit juice sweetness on a very soft and semi-fat flow. There is a roundness to Red not found in the other four cans and that is the aging! WORD: Smooth WINE: Soft Reds/Fat whites BEER: Creamy ales FOODS: All spice dishes from anywhere in the world, salty fare, pub snacks.

Kodoizumi Hakugyokko Yamahai Muroka Nama.description: 1.8L sizing is available by special order.Please call us at 415-355-9555 for more information.First let me say that there aren’t a lot of Nama Yamahais out there, so this sake is special. The nose is a beefy collection of honey, candy, banana, and birthday cake aromas. This sake is sort of a throwback brew, but with a cleaner and more flavorful twist. It is fat, gooey, thick, plump, juicy and sweet. But the higher acidity doesn’t let this brew drink as sweet as it could. There are plenty of chewy flavors to look for like honey, banana, and sweeet rice all of which give this sake a late harvest feel to it. If you are into sake exploration this sake is a prime example of a brew that is affected by its acidity in a sense that it tames a thick and sweet beast. It’s sort of a brewing wonder and add to that the fact that it is nama and you are partaking in a very unique sake drinking experience. WORD: Fat WINE: Fruity reds/Chewy whites/Dessert wines BEER: Sweet ales FOODS: It’s so unique that it plays very well on all types of menus.

Kubota Suiju Daiginjo Nama.description: The nose on this sake made for summer release is a splendid collection of cherry, melon, berry, and bright rice aromas. First of all this is nama Daiginjo and there aren’t too many of those out there. Secondly, it’s from a brewery that is known for making great prototypical Niigata Daiginjo sakes that are light and dry. This Kubota brew is no exception as it drinks clean, round, soft and very balanced. There is a fruit forward presense but this does not mean sweet, and the finish is very quick and gone. There are hints of melon, cherry, pear, and crisp apple on a silky flow that promotes more fruitiness as the fluid warms. A white wine glass brings out more smoothness and balance. WORD: Elegant WINE: Fruity reds/ Tight whites BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: Take To A Sushi Bar

Minato Tsuchizaki Yamahai Nama Genshu.description: This raw and high-alcohol (21%) brew has ricey, yeasty, minerally and kiwi elements in its aroma make-up. In a word, this sake is a smack in the chops, which is velvety, fat, juicy, extremely expressive and drinks with lots of tingle. Full-bodied and crisp! Not as fruity as the "other can" this beefy Yamahai is on the dryer side for all that is going on. Dig deep and find cinimon and persimmon hints amongst the zesty and yeasty layers. A larger vessel distributes all of the big alcohol and acidity play better than a smaller cup. WORD: Bold WINE: Massive Reds/Thick whites (Cocktails) BEER: Stouts FOODS: Spicy cuisine, cocktail scene snacks, pizza, ribs.

Misuzu Tokubetsu Junmai Muroka Nama.description: The nose on this “Namazake” (unpasteurized sake) is a fun collection of berries, prunes, dates, figs, and cranberries. In a word, this is a big and brash brew that is bright and zesty. It speaks to those who like a lot of story in their glass. Using Miyamanishiki rice milled to 55% and having an alc. content of 17%, it fills a glass with lots of frisky edges. This sake drinks with a snappy goodness that is very lively and robust. Look for crisp tangy citrus fruit tones with hints of honey, mint, yellow cherries and persimmon flavors. There is semi-sweet beginning that dances with an elevated acidity play that fills the palate and explodes in the finish with a brashness that screams living sake. WORD: Lively WINE: Deep Reds/Crisp Ales BEER: Crisp Ales FOODS: International Spice from curry to tacos and from Thai to Vietnamese.

Narutotai Ginjo Nama Genshu.description: We used to refer to this wonderful Can as “Beau-shu” because the owner, Beau Timken, discovered this sake on a trip to Tokushima to visit this brewery. It was an exclusive sake at True Sake for the the first year in the States, but we wanted everybody to enjoy this super special sake, and today it is one, of if not the top imported unpasteurized sake. It is a signature “Genshu” or undiluted (18.5% alc) sake with fruity licks but dry tricks. The perfect “semi” sake that is semi-dry, semi-sweet, semi-bold, semi-thick, and semi-rich, but fully fun! Round and tingly. It has deep rich pear, white grape, and melon tones with a hint of citrus and rock candy. Lively, brisk and zesty. It drinks with a crisp attitude that appeals to all wine lovers. Truly one of the best selling sake in True Sake history! It was the first brew that we simply could not keep on the shelf! And if you see a can you should grab it quickly. WORD: Superb WINE: Zesty Dry Reds/Crisp Whites BEER: Crisp Ales. FOODS: The kitchen sink! Super food friendly. Updated 2019/02Vivid, voluptuous and vibrant sake in a can? You bet! This exclusive unpasteurized brew is Beau Timken's prized sake offering for True Sake customers. With a nose of strawberry, watermelon, sweet rice and cinnamon this undiluted sake (18.5%) is fat, happy, bright and chewy. Fruity, but not overly sweet, think big thoughts when tasting this velvety Nama that is pure pleasure in a can. (Yes cans keep sake colder longer!) This abundantly flavored sake is available only at True Sake! WORD: Jolly WINE: Cabernet/non-oaky chardonnay BEER: Belgian Ales FOODS: If it's on a plate or in a bowl it works!

Narutotai Ginjo Namachozo Can.description: The nose on this well packaged single pasteurized sake is a gentle collection of steamed rice, roasted nuts, mineral, and yeast aromas. This fun little can is extremely drinkable. Maybe that’s why they provide the cup! Light, clean, creamy, and bright. It has a long tail that reminds you that you are drinking sake. Not too fruity and not too dry. It is a silky drinking experience. The sake itself drinks more expressive in a wine glass with hints of rice-based desserts, nougat, steamed rice, and rice candy. Basically, it is a clever smooth operator that actually works warmed as well with hints of cocoa emerging as the fluid warms. Cool brewery and a cool can! WORD: Smooth WINE: Round reds/Dry whites BEER: Clean ales FOODS: Clean fare and snacks.

Rokkasen Ginjo Nama.description: The nose on this very fun “Namazake” (unpasteurized sake) is a collection of blueberry, watermelon, white grape, and mineral aromas. Smooth, fresh, clean, and layered this brew drinks juicy with an almost snow cone-like quality that has minerals mixed with hints of young mango, concord grape, pear, and lots of snow melt! Good body, good texture, and great feeling this Ginjo drinks clean and smooth with a quick finish that makes the bottle finish quickly too! The brewers recommend drinking this brew very cold to capture the freshness. Which means it’s perfect for picnics in an ice chest! WORD: Juicy Clean WINE: Gentle Reds/Clean Whites BEER: Light Beer FOODS: Shellfish, crab, oysters, sashimi, clean sushi, and fruit plates.

Shirataki Jozen Mizuno Gotoshi Junmai Gi.description: Woot! They finally starting exporting unpasteurized sakes from one of the best breweries in Japan! The nose on this special sake is a gentle collection of apple, mineral, sweet rice, and citrus tones. Say Hello to a very elegant and gentle nama sake that has controlled flavors on a fluid that is extremely drinkable. Clean, round, dry and layered this brew is the antithesis of the large, fruity, and zesty other nama Junmai Ginjos in the fridge. It is a great example of Niigata-style clean and dry sakes but in a raw form. Look for hints of apple and pear flavors that snap to attention especially in a larger glass that pushes the acidity to the sides of the palate. If this brew feels or tastes familiar there is a very good chance that you have tasted it before but in its pasteurized form! They elevate the acidity for the nama release and take note of the great balance. WORD: Dry WINE: Dry Reds/Clean Whites BEER: Minerally Ales FOODS: This brew does well at the sushi counter for certain or clean grilled fare.

Takachiyo 59 Yamadanishiki Junmai Daigin.description: The nose on this “special” version of the Takachiyo 59 series is a special collection of banana, mango, pear, bamboo, and steamed rice aromas. This Junmai Daiginjo is a little bit different and that is okay! Using high-end Yamadanishiki brewing rice milled to 38% this brew like the others uses the 1801 brewing yeast, which is a little uncommon for Yamadanishiki. The result is a sake that is fat, fleshy, and full-bodied but spritzy (almost effervescent) which is really unique. Smooth, rich, and round this “Extra Edition” has layers of flavors like honey, pear, apple and very different lemon custard element as the brew warms in the glass.
